Droculah2 minutes ago
Cleaning in VR instead of real life....

...and having fun doing it! I do not want to spray down my home, pick up trash, and put away dishes, but for some reason, it's fun in VR. Go figure!

I have only played through a few jobs so far (I wonder how many there are), so I still have more to explore, but here is my review so far. And will update as I play more.

The graphics are OK. Not amazing, not horrible, and it's what I expected, so I'm fine with it.

From the menu, you can shop for items from different categories, buy houses, or accept and complete jobs.

So far, I've cleaned up a writer's home, picked up after a woman's messy cat, and cleaned up the house of a woman who went on a business trip, only to find, once she'd returned, that her lazy husband trashed the house. 

This has essentially consisted of picking up trash with a grabber, spraying and scrubbing dirty spots, righting items that have fallen over, and watering plants. There may be more as I take new jobs, but that's what I've gotten to so far. Each job seems to introduce another mechanic.

When you accept a job, you are brought over to that location, and receive a list of tasks to complete.

You can still change things in the houses you visit, even if they're not part of your task list. For example, I still put dishes away in the cabinets, because they were all over and bothering me, even though it had no effect on the reward or the tasks whatsoever.

Completing jobs earns you money, and skill points. You can purchase items with the money through the shop menu, and level up skills in a skill tree with the points. I have not delved into the skill tree aspect yet, but you can up your skills in various cleaning categories. You can also purchase homes, through the menu, but I have not gotten there yet either. I assume you may be able to decorate these houses with items you purchase, once reaching that stage.

I'm looking forward to cleaning up more houses, and then purchasing some of my own to decorate.

Areas of improvement:

- The controls are really touchy. If you want to open a cabinet or fridge, you often rip them out of the wall or pick them up, rather then easily being able to grip the handles. Placing the items back are touchy too. I'm sure there will be more tutorials as I play, but earlier on you can mess with object placement already. And because there hasn't been a tutorial yet at that point, it can be confusing. For example, I just learned about the grid placement system, which makes it easier to place things, but it took until my third job to discover that.

- Currently, you can choose between seated, standing, and room-scale. You can teleport, or walk around. I think an option for free locomotion is needed. Most people probably won't have the space for walking around in real space. And teleporting is awkward and Immersion-breaking. Being able to love with the controllers freely would be a huge plus.

- The tutorials (so far) can use some work and more explanation.

My thoughts so far is that this is going to be a fun title, and price point seems fair for what it is. But will need some updates, for sure. After having just played for a little, today, I'm already satisfied with my purchase, if that helps anyone decide on whether to get this or not.

Fun!.. with some hiccups

Love this, tried it for PC a while back, wasn't that bothered about it but in VR it's a different story. Simulations like this are perfect for VR, I mean if your going to buy a game where your simulating real life how better than with VR.

There are some things that need improvement though. The movement for one as it's only teleport and can be tricky at times to get around, plus the sense of immersion would defiantly increase with locomotion for sure. All in all its a great little game, it's cheap enough I'd say and I'm excited to see what updates they bring to it. Would love to see more ways to decorate your house and maybe some new tools.
